text.21:
Allah adds an explanation in the context of His rejection of the polytheists' assumption that they worship angels because of Allah's will, with His saying, "Have We ever given them a book before the Qur'an to which they are holding fast? No, not at all. Their stance is only based on conjecture and suspicion containing falsehood," Allah's saying:

They follow not except assumption, and they are only making conjecture. (al-An'am/6: 116)
text.22:
Allah clarifies that what is thought to be a reason for associating partners with Allah is completely untrue and has no reliable basis. They merely blindly follow and adhere to what their ancestors have done, because they are convinced that their ancestors were knowledgeable and would not mislead those who followed them; rather, they would receive guidance. They twist the situation, because in reality they have gone astray and have not received guidance, as Allah says:

Indeed, they have gone astray and have not been guided. (al-An'am/6: 140)
text.23:
In this verse, Allah comforts the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) by stating that no messenger was sent to a land before Muhammad (peace be upon him) who received a heartwarming welcome. They all received responses that were unpleasant to hear and very irritating. This attitude stemmed from people accustomed to a luxurious life, arrogance, and pride. They said, "Indeed, we found our forefathers following a religion, and indeed, we are followers of their footsteps." So, if Muhammad (peace be upon him) receives such a response, he should not be upset or feel constricted in his chest. What was said to Muhammad (peace be upon him) was also said to the previous messengers, as Allah says:

"Nothing is said to you except what was already said to the messengers before you." (Fussilat/41: 43)

Likewise, if it is said that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) is a magician or madman by his people, it is because the previous messengers were also accused of the same by their people, as Allah says:

"Similarly, no messenger came to those before them except that they said, "A magician or a madman."" (adh-Dhariyat/51: 52)
text.24:
Allah explains that the Prophet Muhammad called his people with the words, "Even if I bring you a religion that is clear and better than what your forefathers adhered to, will you still follow in the footsteps of your ancestors?" His people answered arrogantly, that they would still follow in the footsteps of their ancestors and would not follow the religion he brought, namely the religion he was tasked to convey, and they would continue to deny it, as Allah says:

Those who were arrogant said, "Indeed, we disbelieve in that in which you have believed." (al-A'raf/7: 76)
text.25:
Allah clarifies that those who persistently rebel and constantly deny the messengers sent to them and deny the divinity of Allah, will be destroyed as a consequence of their actions of always denying the verses of Allah; may this be witnessed and become a lesson, in accordance with His word:

"So travel through the earth and see what was the end of those who denied (the messengers)." (an-Nahl/16: 36)
text.26:
Allah commanded Muhammad saw to warn his people, who were fanatical about their ancestors, that Prophet Ibrahim had disavowed his father and his people when he saw them earnestly worshipping idols, because that was an inappropriate thing to do and led to misguidance, as Allah says:

And [mention, O Muhammad], when Abraham said to his father Azar, "Do you take idols as deities? Indeed, I see you and your people in manifest error." (al-An'am/6: 74)
text.27:
In this verse, Prophet Ibrahim affirms his stance after disassociating himself from his father and his people, that he only worships Allah who created him and who created all of mankind. He is the One who will show the good and right path, which will lead mankind to happiness in this world and the hereafter. He is the One who provides and gives food and drink, and heals the sick. The Lord who causes death and gives life, the Lord who is hoped to forgive sins in the hereafter. Prophet Ibrahim's affirmation is immortalized in the Al-Qur'an as Allah says:

"(He) who created me, and He [it is who] guides me. And it is He who feeds me and gives me drink. And when I am ill, it is He who cures me. And who will cause me to die and then bring me to life. And who I aspire will forgive me my sin on the Day of Recompense." (ash-Shura/26: 78-82)
text.28:
Allah explains that Prophet Ibrahim made the word of Tawhid (Oneness of God) an everlasting word, so that the people of Mecca could realize it, then abandon the misguided religion of their ancestors and follow the religion of Tawhid embraced by their ancestors who were not misguided, namely Ibrahim, especially if they remember that Prophet Ibrahim is their pride because he built the Baitullah (House of Allah) which became the Qibla (direction of prayer) for Muslims worldwide when performing Salat (prayer).

Qatadah said, "From the descendants of Ibrahim, there will always be those who worship Allah until the Day of Judgment." And Ibn 'Arabi said, "Indeed, the descendants of Ibrahim can inherit the religion of Tawhid, because of two of his prayers that have been granted by Allah, first:

"Indeed, I will make you a leader for the people." [Ibrahim] said, "And of my descendants?" [Allah] said, "My covenant does not include the wrongdoers." (al-Baqarah/2: 124)

and second:

And keep me and my sons away from worshipping idols. (Ibrahim/14: 35)
text.29: Allah explains that He has bestowed blessings upon the polytheists and their ancestors since ancient times, lengthening their lives, granting them various kinds of blessings, but they were captivated by the blessings they possessed, influenced by the desires of their passions, then followed the invitations of Satan and forgot the word of Tawhid (Oneness of God). Then Allah made from the descendants of Ibrahim (Abraham) those who affirmed the Oneness of Allah, commanding the disbelievers among them to believe in Him. Then He chose Muhammad (peace be upon him) as a Messenger and revealed the Qur'an as a book containing guidance to the right path, calling them to do good deeds for the benefit and happiness of this world and the Hereafter.
text.30: Allah explains that when the Qur'an and miracles were presented to them as proof of the Messenger's truthfulness, they responded with an unfavorable reception. They said that what was brought to them was magic and not revelation from Allah, therefore they denied it.
text.31: They said, "The position of a messenger is a noble position, so it is fitting that the person who holds that office is also a noble person, possessing wealth and high status, whereas Muhammad saw does not possess such things. The one who is worthy of holding this position is one of two people who possess these things from two noble cities as well, namely al-Walid bin al-Mugirah from Mecca or 'Urwah bin Mas'ud ats-Tsaqafi from Thaif."
text.32:
This verse demonstrates a rejection of the desires of the polytheists who refused to accept the appointment of Muhammad (peace be upon him) as a messenger; as if they were the most entitled and authorized to distribute and determine who was worthy of receiving God's mercy. Allah states, "Certainly not! We are the ones who have the right and authority to regulate and determine the livelihood of servants in worldly life. We are the ones who elevate some servants above others; some are rich and some are weak, some are intelligent and some are foolish, some are advanced and some are backward, because if We made all servants equal in these matters, there would be competition among them, or there would be no situation of mutual assistance between one another, and there would be no mutual benefit between one another, instead they would mock each other. All of that would lead to the destruction and corruption of the world. If they are unable to do as mentioned above regarding worldly affairs, why do they dare to oppose Allah's various wisdoms in determining who is worthy of being entrusted with the task of prophethood?"

This verse is concluded with an affirmation that Allah's mercy and the virtue given to those who have been destined to hold the office of prophethood and follow the guidance of revelation in the Al-Qur'an that has been revealed, is far better and more noble than the luxury and wealth of the world that they hoard. This is because the world with all its wealth is on the edge of a cliff that will collapse and will disappear without a trace.
text.33: This verse affirms that if it were not for Allah's intention to prevent all people from becoming one community in disbelief because they see the disbelievers receiving abundant sustenance, thinking that abundant wealth is proof of Allah's love for them, then Allah would have given those disbelievers luxurious houses made of gold and silver. But Allah desires their faith.
text.34:
Similarly, the doors of the houses of the disbelievers, and the beds on which they sleep, will be made of silver. All of that is adornment with which people boast; all of that is merely the enjoyment of worldly life, which is temporary in nature, and only lasts for a short time before disappearing and vanishing, while the Hereafter, which is full of diverse and countless pleasures and delights, and is eternally everlasting, has been prepared for those who are pious to Allah, who do not associate partners with Him, who do not commit disobedience by violating His commands, but are obedient and compliant in carrying out His commands. Allah says:

"But you prefer the worldly life, While the Hereafter is better and more enduring." (al-A'la/87: 16-17)
text.35:
Similarly, the doors of the houses of the disbelievers, and the beds they sleep on, will be made of silver. All of that is adornment with which people boast; all of that is merely the enjoyment of worldly life, which is temporary and only lasts for a short time before disappearing, while the Hereafter, which is full of diverse and countless pleasures and delights, and is eternally everlasting, has been prepared for those who are pious to Allah, who do not associate partners with Him, who do not commit disobedience by violating His commands, but are obedient and compliant in carrying out His commands. Allah says:

"But you prefer the worldly life, While the Hereafter is better and more enduring." (al-A'la/87: 16-17)
text.36:
In this verse, it is emphasized that whoever turns away from the reminders and teachings of Allah, that is, blinds their heart to believe in and trust His teachings contained in the Al-Qur'an, then Satan will always accompany them and will always strive to lead them to error, so that Allah will eventually make that Satan their constant companion.

According to az-Zajjaj, the meaning of this verse is that whoever turns away from the Al-Qur'an and does not want to follow the guidance contained within it, Satan will continuously tempt them until they fall into the wrong path, therefore they will surely receive Allah's punishment. In a hadith, the Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

The Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "There is no one among you except that he is accompanied by a companion from the jinn." (Narrated by Muslim)

In another verse, Allah states that those who constantly deny the verses of Allah, their hearts and vision will be turned away by Allah so that they will not believe and remain in their error:

And We will turn away their hearts and their eyes, just as they did not believe in it the first time, and We will leave them wandering blindly in their transgression. (al-An'am/6: 110)

A misguided person will commit sins, and the more they wallow in sin, the more their heart will be sealed, making it impossible to believe and do good, as the Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

The Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "Indeed, if a believer commits a sin, there will be a black dot in his heart. If he repents, abandons it, and asks for forgiveness, his heart will return to being clean. But if his sins increase, the black dot will increase until it covers his heart." (Narrated by Ahmad)
text.37: This verse explains the consequence of taking Satan as a friend, which is that Satan will always strive to prevent them from finding the right path, namely believing in the teachings of Allah found in the Qur'an. They ultimately do not find the right path, but feel that the misguided path they are on is correct, and that the truth of the verses of the Qur'an conveyed to them is wrong. Such is the great power of Satan over that person.
text.38:
This verse explains the fate of people who befriended devils on the Day of Judgment when facing Allah. At that moment, the person realizes that he has been misled by those devils. Before Allah, he regrets why he was too close to those devils when he was in the world. He regrets why, when they were in the world, they and the devils were not as far apart as the east and the west, that is, like between one end and the other. But that regret is useless, because the world has been rolled up and cannot possibly be returned.

In the afterlife, the devils who were their loyal friends in the world will abandon them. Before Allah, those devils deny the friendship and disclaim responsibility, as informed in Surah Ibrahim/14: 22.

And Satan will say when the matter has been concluded, "Indeed, Allah had promised you the promise of truth. And I promised you, but I betrayed you. But I had no authority over you except that I invited you, and you responded to me. So do not blame me; but blame yourselves. I cannot help you, nor can you help me. Indeed, I deny your association of me [with Allah] before." Indeed, for the wrongdoers is a painful punishment. (Ibrahim/14: 22)

Thus, devils are clearly the worst of friends: in the world they seduce, but in the afterlife they disclaim responsibility and even plunge people into ruin.
text.39: Furthermore, Allah affirms to them that no matter how much they regret and whatever their reasons, they will not be accepted. This is because they have committed injustice, which is not believing in Him and not carrying out His commands. They will ultimately be thrown into hell along with the devils who are their companions.
text.40:
In this verse, Allah asks Prophet Muhammad (saw), who always desired that the disbelievers would believe, whether he was able to make the deaf hear the call to believe and do good, and whether he was able to open the hearts of those whose inner eyes were closed. Of course, the Prophet (saw) would not be able to, because only Allah is able to do so, and Allah will not return those who are astray if they themselves are not willing to return to the right path.

Allah's (swt) question to Prophet Muhammad (saw) was not intended as a question, but rather to affirm that their ears and inner eyes were actually deaf and blind, therefore they would not accept any truth conveyed to them. Therefore, his duty as a messenger was only to convey. In conveying Allah's words to the disbelievers of Mecca, the Prophet (saw) had carried it out with all his strength and effort, but some of them opposed him. The Prophet (saw) and his followers were boycotted, and even threatened with death. To save himself, the Prophet (saw) ordered his followers to migrate, first to Abyssinia, and then to Medina. This opposition and threats sometimes made the Prophet (saw) feel disappointed and almost despair. However, with the revelation of verses such as this one, his heart was comforted again. He realized that he was not at fault, but that it was they who had closed their hearts. Only Allah is able to open them, therefore he no longer despaired, but continued to preach, hoping that one day Allah would send His guidance to them.

In another verse, Allah says regarding the granting of guidance, which is Allah's prerogative:

It is not [required] of you, [O Muhammad], to guide them, but Allah guides whom He wills. (al-Baqarah/2: 272)
text.41: In these two verses, it is explained that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) need not worry too much about the opposition of the polytheists of Mecca. They will surely be punished by Allah at the time He wills. This punishment is possible in two ways. First, Allah will punish them after the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) dies; thus, he will not witness the punishment himself in this world. Second, the punishment against the disbelievers is carried out by Allah now, that is, while the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) is still alive. Evidence of such punishment, according to some scholars, is the killing of many leaders of the Meccan disbelievers in the Battle of Badr. Such is Allah's threat against the disbelievers. This statement reaffirms the Prophet's (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) heart that those who oppose him are indeed blinding their hearts, therefore, they need to be preached to more intensively.
text.42: In these two verses, it is explained that the Prophet (saw) does not need to worry too much about the opposition of the polytheists of Mecca. They will surely be punished by Allah at the time He wills. The possibility of that punishment is in two ways. First, Allah will punish them after the Prophet (saw) dies; thus, he will not have the opportunity to witness the punishment himself in this world. Second, the punishment against the disbelievers is carried out by Allah right now, that is, while the Prophet (saw) is still alive. Evidence of such punishment, according to some scholars, is the killing of many leaders of the Meccan disbelievers in the Battle of Badr. Such is Allah's threat to the disbelievers. This statement reaffirms the Prophet's (saw) heart that those who oppose him are indeed blinding their hearts, therefore they need to be preached to more intensively.
text.43: In this verse, the Prophet (saw) is asked by Allah to hold fast to the Al-Qur'an, that is, to further increase his faith in it and to more diligently convey Allah's teachings within it. This is because the teachings contained in the Book are absolutely true and guarantee the happiness of human life in this world and the hereafter. As for those who continue to rebel, of course Allah will determine a punishment for them.
text.44:
Allah affirms that the revelation of the Qur'an is indeed an honor for the Prophet saw and his people, namely the Quraysh tribe in particular and the Arab nation in general. This is because the Qur'an was revealed in their language. In this way, the Arab people, especially the Quraysh tribe, would certainly be the most understanding of its meaning, therefore they should be the first to believe in it and implement the teachings contained within it. In another verse, Allah declares the Qur'an as an honor that has been given to them:

"Indeed, We have sent down to you a Book (the Qur'an) in which is your reminder. Then will you not reason?" (al-Anbiya'/21: 10)

Furthermore, the polytheists of Mecca should have been pioneers in spreading the teachings contained in the Qur'an. For all of this, they will be held accountable. If they do not believe in it, do not implement it, and do not disseminate it, then their position will be replaced by other peoples, as Allah says:

"Here you are - those invited to spend in the cause of Allah - but among you are those who withhold [out of greed]. And whoever withholds only withholds [benefit] from himself; and Allah is the Free of need, while you are the needy. And if you turn away, He will replace you with another people; then they will not be like you." (Muhammad/47: 38)

Because the Qur'an was revealed in Arabic, Muslim communities who are not Arabs and do not speak Arabic need to learn Arabic in order to understand the teachings contained within the Qur'an well. Among them, there needs to be those who delve into the teachings contained within it, implement them, and propagate them. If they do so, then their position is equivalent to the Quraysh tribe who were granted the honor of being the first people to receive Islam and spread it to other nations. They are the scholars (ulama). Thus, on the shoulders of the scholars lies a great responsibility, and they will also be held accountable later in the Hereafter by Allah swt.
text.45:
This verse contains a reproach against the disbelievers of Mecca who were still unwilling to believe and continued to worship idols. The reproach is directed at them because the Qur'an was revealed in their language, where they should have been the ones to understand it better and believe in it first.

For this reason, Allah asks Prophet Muhammad to ask the previous messengers if Allah had ever made any deity other than Himself. The command for the Prophet to ask the previous prophets, according to some scholars, occurred during the Prophet's Isra' Mi'raj. Others are of the opinion that the questioning of the messengers was done by examining the contents of previous holy books, namely the Torah and the Gospel. These prophets would surely answer that they had never witnessed a God other than Allah. Thus, Allah's command to Prophet Muhammad to ask the previous prophets was not asking out of ignorance, but asking to show that the Quraysh who worshipped idols were wrong because it had never been taught in previous religions. Therefore, they should believe.
text.46:
This verse explains that Allah sent the Prophet Musa (Moses) to Pharaoh and his people to convey the teachings of Allah. Prophet Musa was sent to Pharaoh equipped with several miracles, such as a staff turning into a snake, a radiant hand, and so on. The core of Prophet Musa's call to Pharaoh was for Pharaoh to acknowledge Allah as the Lord who created and sustains the entire universe, and to acknowledge him as His messenger.

The affirmation regarding Prophet Musa also contains an affirmation regarding the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). The disbelievers of Mecca should also believe in Allah as the One and Only God, believe in Muhammad (peace be upon him) as His Messenger, and believe in his primary miracle, which is the Al-Qur'an. Furthermore, this affirmation implies that the religion preached by Prophet Muhammad is the same as that preached by Prophet Musa and all the prophets, which is Islam. Allah says:

"Indeed, the religion in the sight of Allah is Islam." (Ali 'Imran/3:19)
text.47:
This verse explains the attitude of Pharaoh and his people towards the call of Prophet Musa (Moses). They asked Prophet Musa to present evidence of his prophethood, then Prophet Musa presented his miracles, including the staff turning into a snake, the radiant hand, and others. But they laughed at him and mocked him. Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was also treated in the same way by the disbelievers of Mecca. They accused him of being a magician and a liar (shad/38: 4), and accused the Qur'an of being dreams, fabrications, or poems composed by Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) (al-Anbiya'/21: 5).

What is conveyed in this verse alleviates the inner pressure suffered by the Prophet (peace be upon him) due to the strong opposition from the disbelievers of Mecca. From the content of the verse, the Prophet (peace be upon him) learned that it is customary for a prophet to be opposed by his people, therefore he is not the only one being opposed, but all the prophets. He must be patient and steadfast in facing all challenges, just as Prophet Musa was patient and steadfast in facing Pharaoh and his army, so that he obtained victory. Likewise, Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), if he is patient and steadfast, will also gain victory over the disbelievers of Mecca in this world as well, which was later proven by the destruction of the Meccan disbelieving army in the Battle of Badr.
text.48:
In this verse, it is explained that a miracle is an event or something great and extraordinary given to a prophet as proof of his prophethood. However, the miracles given to a prophet are greater than the miracles given to previous prophets. Likewise, the miracles given to Prophet Musa. In Surah al-Isra'/17:101, it is stated that Prophet Musa was given nine kinds of miracles, namely a staff that turned into a snake, a luminous hand, a long drought, the sea splitting, a violent storm, locusts that destroyed crops, lice that caused disease, frogs that became pests, and drinking water that turned into blood, which Allah sent down upon Pharaoh and his people in the form of disasters to awaken them, as Allah says:

"So We sent upon them the flood and the locusts and the lice and the frogs and the blood as distinct signs, but they were arrogant and were a criminal people." (al-A'raf/7:133)

By inflicting these disasters upon Pharaoh and his followers, it was hoped that they would return, that is, believe. But it was not so; they remained defiant.

Likewise with Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), he conveyed to the disbelievers of Mecca his greatest miracle, which is the Al-Qur'an. But they still rejected it and declared that the Al-Qur'an was a dream, a fabrication, or a poem composed by Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).
text.49: Pharaoh and his followers felt the disasters that befell them were extremely terrible, so they pleaded with Prophet Musa to pray to Allah to relieve them of the torment. "O magician!" they said, "Pray to your Lord according to what He has promised you! We will surely accept what you convey." Calling Prophet Musa a magician already showed that they were insulting him and did not believe in him. But Prophet Musa still granted their request, because Allah had indeed promised him that if they believed, the torment would be stopped. Prophet Musa then prayed after they promised to believe, and Allah stopped the torment.
text.50:
After the torment was lifted, it turned out they broke their promise. They remained disobedient. In another verse, this event is also explained:

"And when the punishment fell upon them, they said, "O Moses, invoke for us your Lord by what He has promised you. If you remove the punishment from us, we will surely believe you, and we will surely send with you the Children of Israel." But when We removed the punishment from them until a time which they were to reach, then at once they broke their word." (Surah al-A'raf/7: 134-135)

In that verse, it is explained that they promised that if they were released from those calamities, they would believe and would free the Children of Israel from the torment and enslavement they inflicted upon them. But all of that was just a promise. They did not keep that promise, and even wanted to harm Prophet Musa and his people.
text.51: Pharaoh increasingly demonstrated his arrogance and tyranny. He asked his people, asking to affirm, was not the great kingdom of Egypt his, and not someone else's? Were not the rivers, as sources of life in that land, flowing beneath his palace and within his gardens? That question was to show his arrogance. With that statement, he intended to declare that he was the great and only ruler in that land, who could not be opposed or defeated. Therefore, he would not believe and would not submit to the Prophet Musa. His statement also contained a threat to anyone who followed the Prophet Musa, that they would meet with an unfavorable fate.
text.52:
Pharaoh increasingly displayed his arrogance. He insulted Prophet Musa. He asked his people, once again to affirm, wasn't he the best, while Prophet Musa was a contemptible person because he possessed nothing, such as the power, position, and wealth that he had. And wasn't Prophet Musa so insignificant considering he was unable to even explain something with words. What he meant was Prophet Musa's inability to speak clearly because his tongue was tied, as he acknowledged in his prayer to Allah to strengthen him by sending his brother, Prophet Harun. Allah said:

"And my brother Aaron is more eloquent than me in speech, so send him with me as a helper to confirm me. Indeed, I fear that they will deny me." (al-Qasas/28: 34)

Pharaoh's purpose in asking his people by conveying the shortcomings of Prophet Musa was not to ask but to insult him. He hoped that by presenting Prophet Musa's shortcomings, his people would have a negative view of him and not believe him.
text.53:
Pharaoh gave reasons why Prophet Musa (Moses) did not deserve glory and was not worthy of being believed as a messenger, because he did not have gold bracelets as a sign of his wealth, and was not accompanied by angels as a sign that he was a messenger. Thus, Pharaoh made wealth the benchmark of glory, and visible things the benchmark of truth. Allah does not place the benchmark of glory on material things but on piety, as Allah says:

"O mankind, indeed We have created you from male and female and made you peoples and tribes that you may know one another. Indeed, the most noble of you in the sight of Allah is the most righteous of you. Indeed, Allah is Knowing and Acquainted." (al-Hujurat/49: 13)

Allah does not place the benchmark of truth as a messenger on something that can be sensed, but on the truth of the path he takes, namely on the truth of the revelation he receives from Allah. Allah says:

"Say, "I am only a man like you, to whom has been revealed that your god is but one God. So whoever would hope for the meeting with his Lord - let him do righteous work and not associate in the worship of his Lord anyone." (al-Kahf/18: 110)

The unworthy treatment was also experienced by Prophet Muhammad saw, even more severely. His people did not believe him as a messenger because he had nothing. They asked him, in addition to being rich, to also be able to create extraordinary events to the point that they wanted to see Allah and the angels with their own eyes. Of course, he could not fulfill this request because it was beyond his power and impossible to fulfill. He only replied, "Exalted is my Lord, and I am only a human being who is a messenger."

"Say, "Exalted is my Lord! Was I ever anything but a human messenger?" (al-Isra'/17: 93)
text.54: Pharaoh's efforts to influence and deceive his people were successful. The people of Egypt were obedient to him and unwilling to believe in Prophet Musa, even hating him. They were categorized by Allah as the fasiq, that is, people who had truly violated the teachings of religion and deviated from the truth.
text.55:
The wickedness of Pharaoh and his people became increasingly rampant. They became increasingly oblivious, even considering Pharaoh to be a god. This action had reached its peak, which could no longer be forgiven by Allah and was deeply regrettable. Allah then imposed His punishment when Pharaoh and his army pursued the Prophet Musa and his people to the Red Sea, Allah drowned him in that sea. Thus, he perished because of his arrogance in possessing wealth and power, and the truth was revealed, even though it was carried only by an ordinary human being who had no power whatsoever.

The delay of punishment for the wicked is called *istidraj*, which means that the perpetrator of sin is allowed to commit evil until his sin increases to its peak, when the perpetrator is no longer receptive to advice. When those sins have reached their peak, Allah will no longer forgive him, and then He will impose His punishment. The Prophet said in a narration by Ahmad, at-Tirmidhi, ath-Thabrani and al-Baihaqi:

'Uqbah bin 'Amir narrated that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, "When you see Allah giving a servant worldly pleasures that he desires from the world while he is constantly disobeying Him, then that is *istidraj*." Then the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) recited the verse, "So when they forgot that with which they had been reminded, We opened to them the doors of every (pleasant) thing, until in what they were given they rejoiced, We seized them suddenly, and they were thereupon in despair." (Narrated by Ahmad, at-Tirmidhi, ath-Thabrani and al-Baihaqi)
text.56: The case of Pharaoh is an example worthy of being a lesson for subsequent generations until the Day of Judgment. The lesson is that no one should imitate the arrogant and disobedient behavior of Pharaoh. And that anyone who is arrogant and disobedient will experience the same fate as Pharaoh.
text.57: This verse explains that the Prophet Isa, son of Maryam, was used as an example by the polytheists of Mecca to discredit and mock the Prophet Muhammad saw. This happened when he conveyed the verse, "Indeed, you (disbelievers) and what you worship other than Allah are fuel for Hell," (al-Anbiya'/21: 98). They cheered with joy, thinking they had obtained a reason to prove that the Prophet Muhammad was wrong based on that verse. This was because the Prophet Isa was worshipped by some people. Thus, he would also enter hell along with those who worshipped him. To refute this view, Allah revealed the verse, "Indeed, those for whom the good word has preceded from Us - they will be kept far away from it (Hell)," (al-Anbiya'/21:101). Thus, the Prophet Isa, 'Uzair, and the priests and monks who were obedient and only worshipped Allah, will enter Paradise, and the misguided people who later made them gods besides Allah will enter hell. Regarding Isa himself, who was worshipped by those misguided people, this verse was revealed to refute it, "And when the son of Maryam was presented as an example, immediately your people, O Muhammad, laughed aloud at it," that is, they mocked you because of His word. Furthermore, Allah explains, "He (Isa) was not but a servant upon whom We bestowed favor, and We made him an example for the Children of Israel. And if We willed, We could have made [instead] of you angels to succeed [one another] on the earth. And indeed, he (Isa) will be [a sign for] knowledge of the Hour..."
text.58: This verse explains that the polytheists of Mecca were comparing their gods, namely idols, with the Prophet Isa (Jesus) who had been deified by misguided people before them, asking which was better. In their view, the Prophet Isa was no better than the idols they worshipped, because the Prophet Isa would also enter hell along with them and their gods. Then Allah refuted that view by explaining that they were actually just debating and refuting aimlessly, because that was indeed the characteristic that was already ingrained within them.
text.59: Allah affirms that Prophet Isa is indeed His servant, not His son and not God. He has been granted glory, namely becoming a prophet who conveyed the teachings of Allah in the Gospel. In addition to that, Prophet Isa was made by Him as an example for the Children of Israel regarding the proof of His power, that He creates something through an unnatural process, namely creating a human without a father. By presenting that example, the Children of Israel and anyone after them should not regard him as the son of God and elevate him as God.
text.60: Allah refutes the belief of the polytheists of Mecca that angels are the children of Allah who should be worshipped. This belief is similar to the belief of some of the Children of Israel and those after them concerning Prophet Isa (Jesus). Allah affirms that if He willed, He could create humans to become angels who inhabit the earth in succession, or replace humans on earth who also live and procreate until the Day of Judgment. Then, are these angels the children of Allah and worthy of worship? With this explanation, Allah intends to convey to the polytheists of Mecca that He is capable of creating anything, including things far greater than the creation of Prophet Isa, therefore only Allah is worthy of worship, not His creation.
text.61:
Allah further explains the advantages given to Prophet Isa (Jesus), which will be evidence of the Day of Judgment. This is because Prophet Isa possessed great miracles, such as raising the dead, healing blindness, and so on. These miracles are proof that Allah, who granted them, is capable of creating the Day of Judgment.

In addition, authentic hadiths inform us about the coming of Prophet Isa before the Day of Judgment. These hadiths are narrated from various sources, including Abu Hurairah, Ibn 'Abbas, 'Ikrimah, al-Hasan, Qatadah, and adh-Dahhak, so they are considered *mutawatir* (mass-transmitted) by some scholars. Among these hadiths is:

The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "By (Allah) in Whose Hand is my life, the son of Maryam (Mary) will shortly descend amongst you as a just ruler..." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Thus, the meaning of this verse is that the appearance of Prophet Isa before the Day of Judgment is a sign that the Day of Judgment will come.

Furthermore, Allah asks people not to doubt the coming of the Day of Judgment. Therefore, they must prepare themselves by believing and doing good deeds, so that they can reap the fruits of their faith and deeds in the Hereafter. In this way, humans will live happily forever in the Hereafter.

Allah asks the Children of Israel to follow the teachings that He conveyed to Prophet Isa regarding the existence of the Day of Judgment. The teaching about the existence of the Day of Judgment asks humans to do good as preparation for facing it. This teaching is the straight path that is absolutely true and will certainly lead humans to a happy life in the Hereafter. That straight path is what Islam teaches, which is the religion brought by all prophets, including the last prophet, Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him).
text.62:
Furthermore, Allah warns mankind not to be trapped by the deception of Satan. Man's duty is to worship, which is to serve Allah by offering goodness to the entire universe. In this struggle, he will always be hindered and confronted by Satan. Man must fight against him so that his efforts and struggles in realizing goodness are not stopped by Satan.

Thus, Satan also works hard to bring man down. Because he is indeed man's true enemy. This true enmity arises because Satan is vengeful due to being cursed by Allah and expelled from Paradise, because he refused to prostrate to mankind's ancestor, namely Adam.
text.63:
This verse explains how Prophet Isa (Jesus) truly conveyed his message to the Children of Israel (Bani Israil). Prophet Isa delivered the core teachings he received from Allah SWT, including belief in Allah as the One and Only God, belief in the existence of the afterlife, doing good to fellow human beings, and refraining from evil deeds. Prophet Isa emphasized that the core teachings he conveyed were *hikmah*, namely practicing the religion of *tauhid* which needs to be implemented, that is, performing noble deeds and avoiding evil deeds that will determine the happiness of mankind in this world and the hereafter. (Regarding the details of what *hikmah* is, read Surah al-Isra'/17: 23-39).

Prophet Isa also explained his other task, which was to clarify what the Children of Israel were disputing. Some of these disputes concerned religious matters, for example, regarding whether animals with hooves and the fat of cows and sheep were forbidden (al-An'am/6:146). Prophet Isa came to explain the permissibility of all of these (Ali 'Imran/3:50). According to Ibn Jarir, the disputes concerned worldly matters, not religious ones. This seems to relate to the division of the Children of Israel into various sects that were constantly fighting each other.

After that, Prophet Isa asked them to be pious (*taqwa*), that is, to do what Allah commanded and avoid what He forbade. *Taqwa* is a consequence of faith (*iman*), namely implementing the values contained in the *hikmah* above. This means that faith needs to be proven by the implementation of these good deeds. And Prophet Isa asked his people to obey him, that is, to carry out everything he conveyed and not to constantly dispute religious teachings.
text.64: Prophet Isa affirmed the core of the teachings he conveyed, which is that God is only Allah. Allah is the Lord of all creation, his Lord and their Lord as well. The consequence of taking Allah as Lord is to worship Him and devote oneself to Him. Worshipping Allah means performing acts of worship for Him, and devoting oneself to Him means performing good deeds. Therefore, do not worship anything other than Allah, because that will lead people to stray. That is the straight path, which is the path of righteous living that guarantees happiness in this world and the hereafter. The "straight path" in this verse is *tauhid* and good deeds. The "straight path" in verse 61 is believing in the existence of the hereafter, which also requires good deeds. Thus, the "straight path" in both verses is the same in essence, because faith in Allah requires people to believe in the hereafter and do good, and faith in the hereafter also requires people to believe in Allah and do good.
text.65:
The Children of Israel differed in opinion regarding Prophet Isa (Jesus), both during his lifetime and after his death. The point of contention during his lifetime was that some accepted him as a prophet and a holy man, while others accused him of being the child of an illicit relationship committed by his mother. And after his death, some considered him the son of God, or God himself, while others considered him an ordinary human being sent as a messenger.

This disagreement was so sharp that it formed a great number of opposing sects. They not only splintered but also killed each other (engaged in warfare). Those who held incorrect views among these sects held incorrect views regarding Prophet Isa, as explained in the verses above, and will face a miserable fate, namely a painful torment in Hell on the Day of Judgment.
text.66:
This verse refutes the polytheists of Mecca who misunderstood Surah al-Anbiya'/21:98, that those who worship other than Allah will enter hellfire together with their objects of worship. Prophet Isa (Jesus) was worshipped, therefore, according to them, he would also enter hellfire together with those who worshipped him. Allah has refuted this by explaining about Prophet Isa at length in the verses above. Prophet Isa was indeed worshipped, but those who worshipped him were those who were misguided. Therefore, Prophet Isa will not enter hellfire. Those who will enter hellfire are those who are misguided. Likewise, the misguided people who worship idols, namely the polytheists of Mecca. They, together with their objects of worship, are the ones who will enter hellfire.

In this verse, it is explained that if the polytheists of Mecca still refuse to accept such a clear explanation, Allah asks whether they will not regret it. Because the Day of Judgment will surely come, and when it comes, it will happen suddenly while they are lulled by worldly pleasures. Before it is too late, here Allah asks them to believe in Prophet Muhammad and the religion he preached.
text.67:
This verse explains that on the Day of Judgment, friendships and close relationships between disbelievers, whether the friendships that exist between them or their relationships with the deities they worship besides Allah, will turn into enmity, and they will accuse each other. One friend accuses another of being the reason he entered hell and suffered on that day, while the idols deny the worship performed by their worshippers during their lifetime because the idols, as inanimate objects, know nothing about what their worshippers did during their lifetime. Each disclaims responsibility for the accusations of the other.

What is mentioned above was revealed by Prophet Ibrahim to his people as follows:

And he (Ibrahim) said, "You have only taken, besides Allah, idols as a bond of affection among you in worldly life. Then on the Day of Resurrection you will deny one another and curse one another, and your refuge will be the Fire, and you will have no helpers." (al-'Ankabut/29: 25)

'Ali bin Abi Thalib said, "People who are friends (in the world) will become enemies to each other on the Day of Judgment, except for those who are righteous." 'Ali continued, "There are two believers who are friends, and two disbelievers who are friends. Then one of the two believers dies. He is given the good news of entering Paradise, and he remembers his friends. He says, "O Allah, indeed so-and-so, my friend, used to invite me to obey You and Your Messenger. He invited me to goodness and forbade me from evil, and informed me that I would meet You. Therefore, O Allah, do not mislead him after my departure, until You show him (Paradise) as You have shown me, until You are pleased with him as You are pleased with me." Then it is said to the believer, "Go, if you knew what I have prepared for him with Me, you would laugh much and cry little." 'Ali continued, "Then the other believer dies, so their souls meet. After that, it is said to them, "Let each of you praise his friend." Then each of them says, "(You) are the best of brothers, companions, and friends."

And when one of the two disbelieving friends dies, he is informed that he will enter hell. Then he remembers his friend, so he says, "O Allah, indeed so-and-so, my friend, used to invite me to disobey You and Your Messenger. He invited me to do evil and forbade me from doing good, telling me that I would not meet You. Therefore, O Allah, do not guide him after my departure, until You show him something (hell) as You have shown me, and be angry with him as You are angry with me." Then 'Ali continued, "Then the other disbeliever dies, so their souls meet. After that, it is said to them, "Let each of you praise his friend." Then each of them says, "(You) are the worst of brothers, friends, and lovers." (Riwayat Ibn Abi Hatim)
text.68: In this verse is explained Allah's statement to the believers at the time of the Day of Judgment, when all humans are in confusion and fear. Allah says to them, "O My servants, there is nothing for you to fear or worry about on the Day of Judgment. You have all followed the straight path during your life in the world and have done everything out of love for Me and because you sought My pleasure. Therefore, on this day, you are all under My protection and in My guarantee of security. O My servants, do not be saddened by parting with the world and do not worry about facing life in the future. You should be certain that from this moment on, you are free from all trials and disasters that will befall you, and at this moment you will occupy the best place that is unparalleled, namely Paradise which has perfect bliss."
text.69:
In this verse, it is explained about the servants whom Allah will call upon that Day, namely those servants who have believed in His verses, whose souls have submitted and obeyed Him, who have carried out all His commands and avoided His prohibitions.

In Tafsir Ibn Kathir, it is mentioned that al-Mu'tamir bin Sulaiman from his father said, "At the time of the Day of Resurrection, when people are raised from their graves, there is no one who does not feel fear and worry and confusion. At that time, a voice will be heard, "O My servants, there is nothing for you to fear or worry about on this Day, and do not be anxious." After hearing that, all people hope that they are included among the servants of Allah meant in that call. Then a second call is heard, "O you who believe in Our verses, who submit and surrender to Allah." Hearing that call, the believers rejoice and their sadness, fear, and confusion disappear. While the disbelievers despair.
text.70:
Then, the next call was heard, "O you who have believed, enter, you and your wives, into Paradise, which you were promised, enjoying yourselves and rejoicing therein, enjoying the bounty of Allah that has been bestowed upon you all." Because Allah honors them by admitting them into Paradise.

In another verse, it is explained that those who believe, along with their spouses and descendants who believe, will be elevated in rank in Paradise, like the rank of their fathers whose faith is steadfast and strong. Allah says:

"And those who believe and whose descendants follow them in faith - We will join with them their descendants, and We will not deprive them of anything of their deeds. Every person, for what he earned, is retained." (ath-Thur/52: 21)
text.71: After the believers and their families enter Paradise, servants will come to them carrying golden plates filled with delicious foods and goblets filled with drinks that refresh the body and soul. In Paradise, they will obtain everything they desire, everything that soothes and calms their hearts, everything that is beautiful according to their sight and hearing. The state of Paradise cannot be described beforehand, because all of it has never had an example or comparison in worldly life. It is also stated that those who believe and do righteous deeds will abide forever in Paradise, tasting the pleasures of life therein.
text.72:
Thus is Paradise that will be obtained by those who believe as a reward for their faith and righteous deeds that they have done. Those who believe and do righteous deeds enter Paradise solely because of Allah's mercy and grace. Because the faith and deeds performed by believers vary, they will receive different rewards as well. The person with the best faith and deeds will be placed in the highest level of Paradise, and the person with less faith and deeds will be placed in a Paradise of a lower level.

Abu Hurairah narrated that the Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "There is no one but has a place in Paradise and a place in Hell. So the place of the believer in Hell is inherited by the disbeliever, and the place of the disbeliever in Paradise is inherited by the believer. That is what is meant by the word of Allah, "And that is Paradise which you are made to inherit..." (Narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim)
text.73: In this verse, the types of fruits that believers will obtain in Paradise are explained. They will obtain countless fruits of various kinds with diverse flavors. They can eat them at the time, place, and in the condition that they desire.
text.74:
This verse explains that those who deny Allah in the world, commit forbidden acts, and reject Allah's commands, will be cast into Hell, as a recompense for their disbelief; they will abide therein forever and will not be able to escape even for a moment.

The punishment inflicted upon the disbelievers will not be lightened even in the slightest, so they will be in constant pain and confusion. They will despair because their supplications to Allah to be freed from the punishment will not be answered.
text.75:
This verse explains that those who deny Allah in the world, commit forbidden acts, and reject Allah's commands, will be cast into Hell, as a recompense for their disbelief; they will abide therein forever and will not be able to escape even for a moment.

The punishment inflicted upon the disbelievers will not be lightened even in the slightest, so that they will continuously be in pain and confusion. They will despair because their supplications to Allah to be freed from the punishment will not be answered.
text.76: In this verse, the reason for their punishment is explained. Allah states, "We did not intend to wrong the disbelievers by punishing them, because We had given them sufficient warnings during their life in the world, but they did not heed them at all. Rather, they denied the messengers We sent to them and persecuted those messengers even though sufficient evidence had been presented to them. Because of their actions, they were punished; this means that they themselves wronged themselves."
text.77:
Due to the severity of the torment they suffered, they called upon the angel Malik, the guardian of hell, so that the angel would ask Allah to just let them die, so they would be free from the torment. They said, "O angel Malik, plead with Allah that He would just take our lives, so that we are released or no longer feel this torment." The angel replied, "There is no way for you to escape from this hell because Allah has decreed that you will remain in hell forever."

Allah says:

And those who disbelieve - for them is the fire of Hell. [Death] is not decreed for them so they may die, nor is its torment lightened for them. Thus do We recompense every ungrateful one. (Fathir/35: 36)

In another verse:

But the wretched one will avoid it, [He] who will [enter and] burn in the greatest Fire, Where he will neither die nor live. (al-A'la/87: 11-13)
text.78: To those being punished in hell, it will be said, "O disbelievers, indeed We clarified all that is true and the straight path through Our messengers and Our books when you were in the world. However, you did not accept that truth, in fact, you hated that truth and those who followed it. Therefore, woe to you now and regret it yourselves, at a time when all regret is useless and repentance has also been closed."
text.79:
In this verse, it is explained why the disbelievers are cast into Hell, which is because during their lives in the world they always tried to reject all truth by engaging in various deceptions. Therefore, Allah destroyed and thwarted all their deceptions.

In another verse, Allah says:

"And they plotted a plan, and We planned a plan, while they perceived not." (an-Naml/27: 50)

Allah's saying:

"Or do they intend a plot? But those who disbelieve - they are the ones entrapped!" (ath-thur/52: 42)
text.80:
It is narrated by Ibn Jarir that Muhammad bin Ka'ab al-Quradzi said, "When three people were between the Ka'bah and its covering, two from the Quraysh tribe and one from the Saqafi tribe, one of them said, "What do you think, does Allah hear our conversation?" The second person replied, "If you raise your voice, He hears it, but if you whisper, He does not hear it." The third person said, "If He hears when you raise your voice, then He certainly hears when you whisper." Then this verse was revealed.

Seeing the attitudes and actions of the disbelievers during their lives in the world, they seemed not to believe that Allah knows everything; so it is said about them. "Do they think that We do not hear their secrets and their private conversations? Nay, Our messengers (angels) are present with them, recording."

With this verse, Allah affirms by saying, "We know everything they plan and hear all their whispers, there is nothing that We do not know, besides that, the *malaikat hafadzah* (guardian angels) are always writing and recording all their behavior, both in the form of words and deeds. Allah says:

"(Remember) that the two recording angels are recording, one sitting on the right and one on the left. Not a word does he utter but there is a watcher by him ready (to record it)." (Qaf/50: 17-18)
text.81:
Allah commanded the Prophet Muhammad saw to say to the polytheists of Mecca that if ar-Rahman, the Most Gracious, had a son and they could prove its truth with strong reasons, then the Prophet Muhammad would be the first to acknowledge and glorify Him, just as people honor the son of a king because they honor his father. This opinion is based on the idea that the son of God is part of God, therefore the son's position is the same as His own.

The above understanding shows an affirmation that this is very impossible for Allah. Allah says:

"Had Allah willed to take a son, He would have chosen whom He willed out of what He has created. Exalted is He. He is Allah, the One, the Prevailing." (az-Zumar/39: 4)
text.82: This verse declares the sanctity of Allah from the assumptions of the polytheists by stating, "Glory be to Allah, who possesses the heavens and the earth and all that is within them. He possesses the magnificent 'Arsy (Throne). It is impossible for Allah to have a son as they claim."
text.83: Because those polytheists did not want to change their false and misguided beliefs, Allah conveyed a message to the Messenger of Allah, "O Muhammad, leave those who fabricate lies about Allah by saying that He has a child, discussing their falsehood, and let them live in pleasure in disbelief in this world, until the punishment that Allah has promised them comes."
text.84:
This verse further emphasizes the impossibility of Allah having a son by stating, "And to Him belongs whoever is in the heavens and the earth. And those near Him are not prevented by arrogance from His worship, nor do they tire." (Implied: Only He is worshipped by the inhabitants of the heavens and the inhabitants of the earth, only He is worthy of worship, there is no other, because He is the Lord whose every action has wisdom in creating and doing something according to its nature, purpose, and benefit, and only He is the All-Knowing of their condition, both visible and invisible, and He is the All-Knowing of all the contents of the hearts of men.)

In this verse, two kinds of Allah's attributes are mentioned: *hakim* (wise) and *'alim* (all-knowing). If Allah has the attributes of *hakim* and *'alim*, then surely His son would also have those attributes. However, if we pay attention to the attributes possessed by the one they call the son of God, it turns out that his attributes are different from the attributes of God. Like the idols al-Lata, al-Uzza, and Manat, which were worshipped by the polytheists of Mecca, all are inanimate objects that cannot do or know anything. Likewise, Prophet Isa (Jesus), who is believed to be the son of God by Christians, even though the Christians themselves admit that Isa sometimes did not know and did not have wisdom in carrying out all his actions. Did not Isa once weep when he heard the news of the murder of an innocent person, so that he asked his followers to show him the grave of the murdered person? Such a trait is certainly not appropriate for someone who is believed to be the son of God.
text.85: Glory be to Allah, who possesses and controls the kingdom of the heavens and the earth and all that is in them, and other realms whose essence and condition are not yet known. He is the One who has knowledge of the Day of Judgment. No one knows when the Day of Judgment will occur. To Him is the return of all things, then He will recompense all the deeds of mankind with a fitting reward.
text.86:
This verse explains that all idols and deities are worshipped by the polytheists in order to obtain their intercession, even though these idols have no power to act and possess nothing, and are in fact controlled and owned by their worshippers. Is it possible for them to give intercession in such a state? As for those who utter the kalimat tauhid (the declaration of God's oneness), understand and believe in it, and walk according to Allah's guidance, such as the angels and Prophet Isa (Jesus), their intercession is beneficial in Allah's sight, and Allah will grant intercession to those who deserve it.

Sa'id bin Jubair said, "The meaning of this verse is: idols do not give any intercession at all; those who can give intercession are only those who acknowledge the truth, believe in Allah based on learned knowledge, and their far-sightedness."
text.87: This verse explains that the words and deeds of the polytheists contradict each other. If they are asked who created all of these creatures, they answer and acknowledge, "Only Allah created them, without any partners." They are unable to refute this reality, but their actions and deeds prove that they associate partners with Allah. Why do these polytheists turn away, worshipping others besides Allah or only worshipping Allah in accordance with their acknowledgement? This demonstrates their ignorance.
text.88:
Muhammad SAW said, "O my Lord, indeed those whom I call to follow Your teachings according to Your command are people whose hearts have been sealed shut, so they are unwilling to believe." Allah said:

Indeed, those who disbelieve - it is all the same for them whether you warn them or do not warn them - they will not believe. (al-Baqarah/2: 6)
text.89:
After Allah heard the words of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), He said, "O Muhammad, turn away from them, do not despair because of their arrogance to believe, do not heed their evil words, and the actions that humiliate you and your followers, forgive them, later they will acknowledge their mistakes and feel the consequences of their disbelief."

This verse is a promise from Allah to the Muslims, and that promise was fulfilled with the conquest of the city of Mecca. This event caused people to enter Islam in droves. Thus, the religion of Islam spread to all corners of the world in a short time.

Allah says:

When the victory of Allah has come and the conquest, And you see the people entering into the religion of Allah in multitudes, Then exalt [Him] with praise of your Lord and ask forgiveness of Him. Indeed, He is ever Accepting of repentance. (an-Nasr/110: 1-3)
